Article Title: IBM CEO Arvind Krishna says not due to AI, many companies are laying off but because they …
Article Text:
Krishna says AI-led jobs cuts will not be catastrophic







IBM CEO Arvind Krishna has refuted the narrative that the current wave of mass layoffs across the tech industry is primarily due to the artificial intelligence (AI) technology, arguing that the job cuts are largely a “natural correction” following over-hiring during the pandemic years. Krishna, however, acknowledged that AI will eventually lead to some job displacement, but suggested that many companies are currently laying off staff because they overhired between 2020 and 2023.In an interview with The Verge, Krishna used strong terms to describe the rapid staffing increases across the industry during the lockdown era."If you look at the total employment numbers, I think people gorged on employment... during the pandemic and the year after," Krishna explained. He noted that some companies saw their employee count spike by "30, 40, 50, 100 percent" from 2020 to 2023.“There is going to be some natural correction. Business is never completely optimized. I think in engineering terms, it’s an underdamped system. When there’s a need, it goes above. Now, it has to correct. It’s probably going to go below what’s needed, and then it’ll hit the correct equilibrium, depending on market demand and growth,” the CEO noted.Notably, earlier this year, IBM announced that it will lay off thousands of employees from its global workforce in the fourth quarter in 2025. It was reported that the company will layoff about 1% of its total workforce – around 2700 employees – by the end of this year.Talking about the long-term impact of AI on employment, Krishna projected a significant but manageable level of job displacement over the next couple of years.“Could there be up to 10 percent job displacement? I believe that’ll be likely over the next couple of years. It’s not 30 or 40 percent, but it is up to 10 percent of the total US employment pool. It is very concentrated in certain areas," he said.Krishna also believes that as AI increases overall productivity, companies will ultimately hire more people, though in different roles.“Now, as you get more productive, companies are going to then hire more people but in different places. We are hiring more because people say, “I don’t need to do the entry-level task because an AI agent can do it.” I’m looking at them like, “Really?” Think strategically for a moment,” the CEO noted.Krishna criticised companies that are looking to AI primarily as a cost-cutting measure for entry-level tasks, calling the approach "shortsighted."“Wouldn’t you rather have an entry-level person and AI makes them more like a 10-year expert? Isn’t that more useful to me than the other way around? Otherwise, where is the talent who’s going to come up with the next great product? Where is the person who’s going to be able to convince a client to deploy technology the way it should be deployed? That’s why I think some are being shortsighted,” he noted.Last month, Krishna said that the company will continue to hire more college graduates.“People are talking about either layoffs or freezing hiring, but I actually want to say that we are the opposite. I expect we are probably going to hire more people out of college over the next 12 months than we have in the past few years, so you’re going to see that,” Krishna told CNN.
Article Summary: IBM CEO Arvind Krishna has refuted the narrative that the current wave of mass layoffs across the tech industry is primarily due to the artificial intelligence (AI) technology. Krishna, however, acknowledged that AI will eventually lead to some job displacement, but suggested that many companies are currently laying off staff because they overhired between 2020 and 2023.

Article Title: South Korea PM Lee Nak-yon pushes stronger data protection laws after Coupang breach
Article Text:
Regulatory push



Coupang apologises over massive data breach







Coupang, South Korea's largest e-commerce platform often dubbed the “Amazon.com of South Korea,” recently faced a massive data breach. The system of the company were illegally accessed causing a massive data breach and affecting the personal information of 33.7 million customer accounts. The breach was first detected by the company on November 18 but it believes the unauthorised access to customer accounts began on June 24 and was executed through overseas servers. Coupang says that the compromised information is limited to basic personal data and the highly sensitive financial details remain secure. Now, the South Korean Prime Minister Lee Nak-yon has called for stronger penalties against companies that fail to protect consumer data.As reported by Reuters, Lee emphasised that the companies must face tougher consequences when they fail to protect personal information. “We cannot allow negligence in data protection to go unpunished,” he said, urging lawmakers to strengthen penalties and enforcement measures.Along with this, Lee also stressed that protecting the trust of the consumer is of critical importance for South Korea’s digital economy, which heavily relies on e-commerce and online services.He also called for closer cooperation between government agencies and private firms to prevent future breaches.For the uninitiated, South Korea already has some strict data privacy laws under the Personal Information Protection Act (PIPA). However, the critics argue that enforcement of the laws has been inconsistent and the penalties are also lenient. The recent Coupang data breach has intensified the calls for higher fines and reforms.Coupang has also apologised for the data leak and urged customers to be wary of phone calls, text messages or other communications impersonating the company. The company also said that it has launched an investigation with security experts into the incident and is working with law enforcement as well as regulatory authorities.Notably, on November 20, Coupang reported a data leak involving about 4,500 customers. At that time, the company said that it had found no evidence of unauthorised access to payment information or into its systems.The latest incident surpasses SK Telecom's data leak in April. It affected 23.2 million users, resulting in a record fine of 134.8 billion won.
Article Summary: South Korean Prime Minister Lee Nak-yon has called for stronger penalties against companies that fail to protect consumer data. Coupang, South Korea's largest e-commerce platform often dubbed the “Amazon.com of South Korea,” recently faced a massive data breach. The breach was first detected by the company on November 18.

Article Text:
Senator Bernie Sanders

Bernie Sanders bankruptcy warning



Bernie Sanders warning on the rise of AI







US senator Bernie Sanders has once again raised an alarm on medical debt crises in America. In a post shared on social media platform X (formerly known as Twitter) Sanders highlights that more than 530,000 America will go bankrupt annually because of the cost of healthcare. In the post, Sanders also drew comparisons of US with other countries like Germany, Canada, France and Japan, where the number of medical bankruptcies is zero.In post shared on X, Sanders shared a chart highlighting the disparity. He mentioned that while advanced economies across Europe and Asia report no medical bankruptcies, the United States stands alone with 530,000 cases each year. “Yes. We need Medicare for All — NOW,” Sanders wrote, underscoring his long-standing push for universal healthcare. He further argued that the present system in the US compels ordinary Americans into financial ruin simply because they get sick, calling it a moral and economic failure.The figures highlighted by Sanders come from a 2019 American Journal of Public health study. The study estimated that medical issues contribute to hundred of thousands of bankruptcies annually. While some analysts debate the methodology, the number has become a rallying point for advocates of healthcare reform.Sanders’ post has reignited debate about the U.S. healthcare system, which remains the most expensive in the world yet leaves millions uninsured or underinsured.Last month, the US senator issued one of his starkest warnings yet about the rise of artificial intelligence. In an interview with NBC News, Sanders said that the technology’s explosive growth risks concentrating wealth and power among a handful of billionaires while leaving ordinary workers behind. Sanders cautioned that AI’s military applications could reshape global conflict. “I think we are not all that far away from the development of robotic soldiers,” he said. “If you don’t have to worry about loss of life, and what you worry about is loss of robots, what does that mean for issues of war and peace globally? It’s a big issue.”

Article Title: Google's Gemini forces OpenAI CEO Sam Altman send 'Code Red' warning to employees, two years after ChatGPT did same to Google
Article Text:
OpenAI faces an internal 'code red' as Google's Gemini surges ahead, forcing a halt on revenue plans to fix ChatGPT's performance. Google's integrated infrastructure and custom chips give it a decisive edge. OpenAI's pivot highlights intense competition and financial pressures, as it scrambles to regain ground against a resurgent tech giant.

Google's infrastructure advantage proves decisive

Financial pressures compound OpenAI’s strategic challenges





Three years after ChatGPT's explosive debut sent Google into panic mode, the tables have turned spectacularly. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has declared an internal "code red" emergency, ordering employees to halt work on advertising and revenue-generating features to fix ChatGPT's deteriorating competitive position as Google's Gemini 3 model surges ahead on performance benchmarks, user engagement, and market share—a reversal that threatens the $500 billion startup's future while vindicating Google's patient, infrastructure-heavy approach to artificial intelligence.OpenAI is abandoning plans to introduce advertising, AI shopping assistants, health agents, and its Pulse personal assistant, according to internal memos obtained by The Wall Street Journal and The Information. Instead, all resources will redirect toward improving ChatGPT's speed, reliability, and personalisation as the company confronts what Altman called "temporary economic headwinds" from Google's aggressive AI offensive. The staff working on chatbot will have to attend daily calls as the development sprints toward an “even more intuitive and personal,” as described by ChatGPT's head Nick Turley."We are at a critical time for ChatGPT," Altman wrote in memo, first reported by The Information. The directive escalates OpenAI's internal alert level from "code orange" to "code red"—the company's highest urgency designation for existential threats.The retreat comes as a remarkable role reversal from December 2022, when ChatGPT's launch forced Google CEO Sundar Pichai to issue his own "code red" that restructured entire divisions and accelerated AI development timelines.Google's comeback stems from advantages OpenAI cannot easily replicate. Its Gemini user base rocketed from 450 million monthly active users in July to 650 million in October, while web analytics firm Similarweb reports users now spend more time with Gemini than ChatGPT—despite OpenAI claiming 800 million weekly users.More fundamentally, Google controls what insiders call the "full stack." DeepMind researchers build models, proprietary TPU chips train them cheaply, Google Cloud hosts them efficiently, and seamless integration delivers them across Search, YouTube, Gmail, and 3 billion Android devices. OpenAI depends on Microsoft's cloud infrastructure and Nvidia's expensive chips, creating structural cost disadvantages."One of the most important things for us at Google is this is possible because we have a very differentiated full-stack approach," DeepMind CTO Koray Kavukcuoglu told reporters, noting the company trains models on custom silicon while deploying them immediately into products.Google's latest Gemini 3 model has outperformed OpenAI's GPT-5 on industry benchmarks, while its Nano Banana Pro image generator has gained significant traction. Anthropic's Opus 4.5 model also beat GPT-5 in key tests, squeezing OpenAI from multiple directions.OpenAI isn't alone in feeling the tremors from Gemini 3's success. Nvidia's stock plummeted over 6%, erasing roughly $250 billion in market value, after reports emerged that Meta Platforms—one of OpenAI's fellow mega-customers—is in advanced talks to purchase billions of dollars worth of Google's TPU chips instead of Nvidia's GPUs. The chipmaker, which supplies the expensive hardware powering OpenAI's models and has built a near-monopoly on AI infrastructure, now faces the prospect of losing up to 10% of its annual revenue as Google's custom silicon proves both cheaper and, for certain workloads, more efficient than Nvidia's flagship products.The pivot comes as OpenAI confronts brutal financial realities. The Wall Street Journal reported the company must reach roughly $200 billion in annual revenue by 2030 to achieve profitability—requiring 100-fold growth while burning billions quarterly on compute costs and talent.Google generates $120 billion annually with nearly $100 billion in cash reserves, giving it unlimited capacity to undercut OpenAI on pricing or outspend on research. The search giant can afford to offer advanced models free while OpenAI desperately needs to monetize.Altman attempted to reassure employees that a new reasoning model launching next week would surpass Gemini 3's capabilities. "I wouldn't trade positions with any other company," he wrote, according to sources familiar with the memo.But the emergency directive—and the shelving of advertising plans OpenAI needs to survive—suggests deeper anxiety about whether the ChatGPT pioneer can maintain its early lead against a tech giant finally operating at full throttle.
Article Summary: Google's Gemini 3 model has outperformed OpenAI's GPT-5 on industry benchmarks, user engagement, and market share. OpenAI is abandoning plans to introduce advertising, AI shopping assistants, health agents, and its Pulse personal assistant. Instead, all resources will redirect toward improving ChatGPT's speed, reliability, and personalisation.

JPMorgan’s move comes as the bank seeks to limit its financial exposure tied to the controversial acquisition of Frank, which prosecutors say was inflated by fraudulent misrepresentations.Javice was 27 years old in summer 2021, when JPMorgan executives agreed to acquire her website.

Article Title: What is Sanchar Saathi, the app that government wants Apple, Samsung, Xiaomi and others to preload on smartphones
Article Text:
India's making a new cybersecurity app, Sanchar Saathi, a must-have on all new smartphones. It's designed to fight phone scams and theft, and it's already been a big help, recovering tons of stolen devices and stopping millions of fake phone lines. Even though Apple might push back, the government says you can ditch the app if you want.

What is Sanchar Saathi app

Sanchar Saathi App Optional Says Centre Amid Fierce Pegasus-Like Snooping Charges and Privacy Debate

Why government wants Apple, Samsung, Xiaomi and other smartphone makers to preload Sanchar Saathi app

From fraud reporting to device blocking, what are the features of Sanchar Saathi app

Apple plans to challenge the compliance

Telecom minister clarifies: Sanchar Saathi app not mandatory to keep, can be deleted





The government has mandated that all smartphones sold in the country must come pre-installed with Sanchar Saathi, a cybersecurity application. The Department of Telecommunications (DoT) issued the directive on November 28, 2025, under the Telecommunication Cybersecurity Amendment Rules, marking the first time India has required state-backed software on all mobile devices. The move affects one of the world's largest smartphone markets, with over 1.2 billion mobile users.Sanchar Saathi, launched in January 2025, is described by DoT as a "citizen centric initiative" designed to empower mobile subscribers and strengthen their security against telecom-related cyber threats. The app is available both as a mobile application and through a web portal at www.sancharsaathi.gov.in, offering various services aimed at protecting India's 1.2 billion mobile users from fraud and device theft.According to government data, the platform has already demonstrated significant impact, helping recover over 700,000 lost phones, blocking more than 3.7 million stolen devices, and terminating 30 million fraudulent mobile connections.The DoT justifies the initiative by citing the prevalence of duplicate or spoofed IMEI (International Mobile Equipment Identity) numbers, which pose serious cybersecurity threats.The department also notes that India's large second-hand mobile device market has seen cases of stolen or blacklisted devices being resold, making purchasers unwitting participants in crime.The app offers several practical services for users. Through its "Chakshu" feature, citizens can report suspected fraud communications, including impersonation scams involving government officials, banks, or police, as well as unsolicited commercial communications (spam). Users can also report malicious web links received through SMS, WhatsApp, Telegram, and other platforms.Another feature allows users to block and trace lost or stolen mobile devices using the phone's unique 15-digit IMEI code. Once blocked through the app, the device becomes unusable across all networks, even if the SIM card is changed.The app also enables users to verify how many mobile connections are registered in their name, helping them identify unauthorized SIM cards. Additionally, users can check the genuineness of their mobile handset by scanning its IMEI barcode to ensure they haven't purchased stolen or counterfeit devices.The directive has encountered resistance from major smartphone manufacturers, particularly Apple. According to Reuters, Apple does not plan to comply with the mandate to preload its smartphones with the state-owned cyber safety app and will convey its concerns to New Delhi, three sources said.While India's smartphone market is dominated by Android devices, Apple's iOS powers an estimated 4.5% of the 735 million smartphones in the country by mid-2025, according to Counterpoint Research. Tarun Pathak, a research director at Counterpoint, told Reuters that "Apple has historically refused such requests from governments," suggesting potential friction ahead as the 90-day compliance deadline approaches.Initially, the DoT directive reportedly stated that the pre-installed application must be "readily visible and accessible" to users during device setup and that its functionalities cannot be disabled or restricted. This sparked questions about user choice and flexibility. However, Minister Scindia quickly addressed these concerns, emphasizing that the app is not mandatory for use."If you want to delete the app, you can, it is not mandatory. For instance, if you don't want to use the app, don't register for it, it will stay dormant, and delete it if you want to," Scindia explained. He added that the government's responsibility is to make the app available to everyone, as many citizens are unaware of this tool designed to protect them from digital frauds and theft.The directive requires manufacturers to complete implementation within 90 days and submit compliance reports within 120 days. For devices already in sales channels, manufacturers are encouraged to push the app through software updates. Sanchar Saathi can be downloaded from both Google Play Store and Apple App Store for users who wish to access its services voluntarily.
Article Summary: India's government has mandated that all smartphones sold in the country must come pre-installed with Sanchar Saathi, a cybersecurity application. The Department of Telecommunications (DoT) issued the directive on November 28, 2025, under the Telecommunication Cybersecurity Amendment Rules. The move affects one of the world's largest smartphone markets, with over 1.2 billion mobile users.

Article Title: “AI could erase America’s debt crisis in just 3 years…”: Elon Musk claims

Elon Musk

Historical precedent of technological breakthroughs

He argues that, when scaled across the economy, similar automation could significantly raise national productivity.In effect, widespread adoption of AI could drive down the relative cost of production, increase the supply of goods and services, and allow the economy to grow in real terms rather than nominal, easing debt burdens over time.Instead of addressing debt through austerity or taxation, Musk’s approach reframes the problem as a growth and innovation challenge. If AI can dramatically increase value creation by automating labour, expanding production, and enabling new industries, then revenue generation can outpace debt obligations, making debt more manageable without painful social or fiscal cuts.To understand why Musk’s proposal gains attention, consider these recent economic signals:In this context, Musk argues that only a sharp boost in productivity delivered by AI can realistically restore long-term fiscal balance while avoiding deep social upheaval.

Apple likely to say 'No', other companies reviewing order

What is Sanchar Saathi app





Telecom Minister Jyotiraditya Scindia has issued a clarification on the Sanchar Saathi app. The minister said that the cybersecurity app is not mandatory for users. "The app is completely optional. If you want to delete it, you can. If you don't wish to register, you shouldn’t register and can remove it anytime," Scindia told reporters outside the Parliament. The telecom minister added that the app does not enable snooping or call monitoring. "But not everyone in the country knows that this app exists to protect them from fraud and theft," Scindia said."It is our responsibility to make this app reach everyone. If you want to delete it, then delete it. If you don't want to use it, then don't register it. If you register it, then it will remain active. If you don't register it, then it will remain inactive. For instance, if you don't want to use the app, don't register for it, it will stay dormant, and delete it if you want to," Scindia explained. He added that the government's responsibility is to make the app available to everyone, as many citizens are unaware of this tool designed to protect them from digital frauds and theft.The report added that the order further says that for devices already in the supply chain, manufacturers should push the app to phones via software updates.Reuters report claimed that the telecom ministry privately asked smartphone makers to preload all new devices with a state-owned cyber security app that cannot be deleted. The Reuters report said that it has seen the government order.According to the Union government, the Sanchar Saathi app helps prevent cyber threats and assists tracking and blocking of lost or stolen phones, helping police to trace devices, while keeping counterfeits out of the black market.The order caused a furore both inside and outside Parliament on Tuesday, with a number of lawmakers accusing the government of introducing an app that would act as a snooping tool. Rahul Gandhi of main opposition Congress Party said he planned to speak about the app in Parliament. The Congress Party has called for a rollback of the mandate. On X (formerly Twitter), KC Venugopal, a top Congress leader, said "Big Brother cannot watch us. "According to a Reuters report, Apple does not plan to comply with a mandate to preload its smartphones with a state-owned cyber safety app and will convey its concerns to the ministry. Apple does not plan to comply with the directive and will tell the government it does not follow such mandates anywhere in the world as they raise a host of privacy and security issues for the company's iOS ecosystem, said two of the industry sources who are familiar with Apple's concerns. They declined to be named publicly as the company's strategy is private. "Its not only like taking a sledgehammer, this is like a double-barrel gun," said the first source.Other brands including Samsung are reviewing the order, said a fourth industry source who is familiar with the matter. Samsung did not respond to Reuters queries.The Department of Telecommunications (DoT) introduced the Sanchar Saathi mobile app in January 2025. According to telecom department, the app complements the existing Sanchar Saathi portal by providing convenient, on-the-go protection against identity theft, forged KYC, device theft, banking fraud, and other cyber risks. As per DoT, Sanchar Saathi app is mainly designed to help users block and track lost or stolen smartphones across all telecom networks, using a central registry. It also lets them identify, and disconnect, fraudulent mobile connections.One of the world's largest telephone markets, India has more than 1.2 billion subscribers. As per government figures, the app has helped recover more than 700,000 lost phones, including 50,000 in October alone. With more than 5 million downloads since its launch, the app has helped block more than 3.7 million stolen or lost mobile phones, while more than 30 million fraudulent connections have also been terminated.The app is available in Hindi and 21 other regional languages, making it inclusive and accessible across the country.
Article Summary: Telecom Minister Jyotiraditya Scindia has issued a clarification on the Sanchar Saathi app. The minister said that the cybersecurity app is not mandatory for users. The order caused a furore both inside and outside Parliament on Tuesday.

Article Title: Nvidia on Google coming for its chip business, says: Happy for them, but ...
Article Text:
Nvidia Makes History: First Company to Hit $4 Trillion Market Cap

Google’s position in the AI race



Wall Street takes notice as competitive dynamics shift







Nvidia, the chipset making giant has now downplayed concerns that Google is coming for its dominance in the AI hardware market, even as reports Meta may spend billions on Google’s custom chips. The comments come at a time when competition is increasing in the AI race and a volatile stretch for Nvidia’s stock. In a statement posted on X, Nvidia said, “NVIDIA is a generation ahead of the industry — it’s the only platform that runs every AI model and does it everywhere computing is done.” The company added: “We’re delighted by Google’s success — they’ve made great advances in AI and we continue to supply to Google.”The remarks made by Nvidia is followed by a report from The Information highlighting that Meta is in talks with Google to potentially use its chips to power data centers, a move that rattled the investors. Also, the share of Nvidia fell more than 3% following this news.According to The Information, Meta could begin renting TPUs from Google Cloud as early as next year, with purchases for its own data centers potentially starting in 2027.This matters enormously because Meta ranks among Nvidia's largest customers, planning up to $72 billion in AI infrastructure spending this year. For Google to capture even a fraction of that business would represent a seismic shift in the AI hardware market.The deal would also mark Google's expansion beyond its current strategy of using TPUs exclusively in its own data centres, positioning the company in direct competition for the hundreds of billions being spent on AI processors.As reported by Business Insider, Google replied by stressing that its commitment to supporting both its own Tensor Processing Units (TPUs) and Nvidia’s GPUs. “We are experiencing accelerating demand for both our custom TPUs and Nvidia GPUs; we are committed to supporting both, as we have for years,” a Google spokesperson said.Recently, Google gained momentum in the AI race after the launch of Gemini 3 and the model also received positive reviews. Unlike many rivals, Google benefits from a “full-stack” advantage, controlling everything from AI research to its cloud infrastructure.The rivalry between Nvidia and Google comes at a time, when the world’s largest company by market capitalisation has faced a turbulent few weeks. The chipmaker reported blockbuster third-quarter earnings, initially calming fears of an AI bubble. But lingering doubts resurfaced as competition from Google and others intensified.

Article Title: Australian teen takes social media ban to court, calls it unsafe
Article Text:
Legal challenge ahead



Government’s position







Australia’s plan to impose a ban on social media platforms such as Instagram, TikTok, Snapchat for children under 16 is now facing a High Court challenge. As reported by Reuters, a 15-year-old student, Noah Jones has become the face of this opposition. Jones said that the law which is said to come into effect from December 10, 2025 will not protect young people but will instead make the internet more dangerous. Jones, who is co-plaintiff in the case alongside another teenage, believe that the ban would be widely circumvented and push young users into less regulated corners of the internet. “This measure will make the internet less safe for young people,” he argued, stressing that social media is essential for staying connected and sharing ideas, likening it to a modern-day town square.As reported by Reuters, a case has been filed against Communications Minister Anika Wells and eSaftey Commissioner Julie Inman Grant. The case has also drawn support from the Digital Freedom Project, an internet rights groups that claims the ban is an “unfair assault on freedom of speech” and violates the implied constitutional right to freedom of political communication.The group is of the point-of-view that banning the internet access for the young people is not the solution, instead they should be taught how to navigate digital spaces safely."We should be cutting off the bad things about social media. When kids do things in secret, that's when things can be really harmful,” Jones told Reuters.Jones said social media is essential for staying connected and sharing ideas, likening it to a modern-day town square. "I have almost all the people in my year on Snapchat. It's a light way of being connected. Most people will get quite separated," he said.The government has however vowed to stand firm against the challenge. Communications Minister Wells said the ban is necessary to protect children from harmful content and online predators, insisting that the government will not be intimidated by legal threats or pressure from big tech companies.The law requires platforms to remove all users under 16 or face hefty fines. Supporters say it will shield minors from exploitation and mental health risks, while critics warn it could backfire by isolating young people and limiting their ability to engage in civic discourse. The debate reflects a broader global struggle over how to balance child safety, digital rights, and free expression in the age of social media.
Article Summary: Australia’s plan to impose a ban on social media platforms for children under 16 is now facing a High Court challenge. A 15-year-old student, Noah Jones has become the face of this opposition. Jones said that the law which is said to come into effect from December 10, 2025 will not protect young people but will instead make the internet more dangerous.

Article Title: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella says humans can't rely on brains alone to succeed at workplace, they need…
Article Text:
In a world increasingly dominated by artificial intelligence, Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella argues that emotional intelligence is essential for business leaders. He posits that while AI can manage technical tasks, the human touch—through empathy and collaboration—remains irreplaceable in driving success.

Satya Nadella Steps Back to Focus on AI: Microsoft’s Major Reorganisation Explained

Social intelligence gains prominence in AI era

CEO reshapes Microsoft’s culture with 'growth mindset' approach





Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella emphasized that emotional intelligence is becoming increasingly vital in the workplace as artificial intelligence takes over more technical responsibilities, calling empathy a crucial business skill rather than just a soft skill.During a recent conversation with Axel Springer CEO Mathias Döpfner on the "MD Meets" podcast that aired November 29, Nadella stated that leaders cannot succeed with intelligence quotient alone. "IQ has a place, but it's not the only thing that's needed in the world," he said in the interview. "I've always felt, at least leaders, if you just have IQ without EQ, it's just a waste of IQ."Nadella added that social intelligence is also becoming key as AI handles more technical tasks. The Microsoft chief executive has consistently maintained that empathy represents an important business capability, not merely a peripheral soft skill.When Döpfner questioned whether the growing importance of empathy influenced Microsoft's decision to implement return-to-office mandates starting early next year, Nadella responded that recognizing the role of human collaboration is even more crucial in the age of AI, describing the workplace as "the best collaboration tool."However, he clarified he doesn't want to be overly rigid about office return policies.Nadella has recently restructured Microsoft's leadership team partly to enhance competitiveness in the AI race, with the company pursuing artificial general intelligence through its new superintelligence team.The emphasis on soft skills comes as many workplaces are starting to value problem-solving, emotional intelligence, and creativity as they delegate more technical responsibilities to AI, according to executives and workplace transformation experts.Nadella's leadership philosophy centers on what he calls a "growth mindset," transforming Microsoft's culture from "know-it-alls" to "learn-it-alls" during his decade-long tenure as CEO. This approach has helped Microsoft achieve significant growth, with its stock climbing almost 20% this year and its market capitalization reaching $3.7 trillion, making it the world's second most valuable company after Nvidia.

He posits that while AI can manage technical tasks, the human touch remains irreplaceable in driving success. The Microsoft chief executive has consistently maintained that empathy represents an important business capability, not merely a peripheral soft skill.

Article Title: After outages that brought down half the internet, Google and Amazon join hands: Here's what it means
Article Text: In a move signaling a shift toward greater cooperation in the competitive cloud market, Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Google Cloud introduced a jointly developed multicloud networking service on Sunday. The initiative aims to bolster internet reliability and drastically reduce the time required to connect disparate computing platforms. The collaboration comes as the tech industry faces increasing pressure to prevent costly service disruptions. The new offering arrives just over a month after a massive AWS outage on October 20 knocked major applications -- including Snapchat and Reddit—offline. That single event is estimated to cost U.S. companies between $500 million and $650 million in losses, according to analytics firm Parametrix.The new service combines AWS’ Interconnect-multicloud with Google Cloud’s Cross-Cloud Interconnect. According to the companies, this integration allows customers to establish private, high-speed links between the two platforms in "minutes instead of weeks." "This collaboration between AWS and Google Cloud represents a fundamental shift in multicloud connectivity," said Robert Kennedy , Vice President of Network Services at AWS.Rob Enns, Vice President and General Manager of Cloud Networking at Google Cloud, noted that the joint network is designed to streamline the movement of data and applications between clouds, addressing a longstanding friction point for enterprise clients.Tech giant Salesforce was named as one of the early adopters of this new interoperable approach.The partnership occurs against a backdrop of surging demand for digital infrastructure, driven largely by the rapid adoption of artificial intelligence. Major players, including Alphabet, Microsoft, and Amazon, are currently investing billions to expand capacity to handle this increased traffic.While the two companies are collaborating on connectivity, they remain fierce competitors. AWS retains its position as the world's largest cloud provider, followed by Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud. In the third quarter, Amazon’s cloud business generated $33 billion in revenue -- more than double Google Cloud's $15.16 billion.However, as internet disruptions become more expensive and disruptive, the new partnership suggests that interoperability is becoming a business necessity even for market leaders.
Article Summary: Amazon Web Services and Google Cloud introduce a jointly developed multicloud networking service. The initiative aims to bolster internet reliability and drastically reduce the time required to connect disparate computing platforms. The collaboration comes as the tech industry faces increasing pressure to prevent costly service disruptions.

Article Title: “I’m a big fan of anyone who…”: Elon Musk’s advice to Indian entrepreneurs goes viral on Nikhil Kamath’s podcast
Article Text:
Elon Musk: A Different Conversation w/ Nikhil Kamath | Full Episode | People by WTF Ep. 16

Why Elon Musk’s advice to Indian entrepreneurs matters

What does Elon Musk’s advice to Indian entrepreneurs highlight about building useful products

Elon Musk’s advice to Indian entrepreneurs focuses on hard work and patience

How Indian entrepreneurs can apply Elon Musk’s advice in a practical way

Also read|





In a recent episode of the popular podcast People by WTF hosted by Indian entrepreneur Nikhil Kamath, Elon Musk shared advice that has quickly gone viral across India. His message, directed towards young Indian entrepreneurs, emphasised the importance of focusing on building useful products and services rather than chasing wealth directly. Musk expressed admiration for creators who genuinely want to contribute something meaningful to society and encouraged founders to build with purpose, resilience and long-term commitment. The podcast sparked wide discussion across social media as many viewers reflected on whether shifting attention from profit to problem-solving could transform India’s fast-growing entrepreneurial landscape and inspire more sustainable innovation across sectors and communities today.During the conversation, Musk said he is a big fan of anyone who wants to build and who wants to create more value than they consume. He encouraged entrepreneurs to focus on solving real problems rather than pursuing rapid financial gain. According to him, when businesses genuinely aim to provide something useful, success naturally follows. The emphasis on meaningful contribution resonated deeply because many new founders feel pressured to grow fast, seek investment early and measure success only by valuation or revenue.Musk’s view suggests that long-term growth depends more on usefulness than hype and that sustainable companies are built by solving needs that truly matter.This perspective reinforces patient innovation by encouraging creators to prioritize authenticity, resilience, thoughtful design, and community impact across every undertaking.Musk’s comments urge Indian entrepreneurs to place value creation at the centre of their strategy. Instead of replicating existing products or following trends simply to seek profit, he encouraged founders to identify gaps in society and build solutions that genuinely improve life for others. Useful products, he suggested, should be the foundation of every venture because they shape trust, create resilience and last longer than businesses based purely on momentum or marketing. The growing pace of India’s digital and industrial development means opportunities are vast. From affordable technology and education to rural services and healthcare systems, providing real utility remains one of the strongest paths to making an impact.Musk also noted that entrepreneurship involves significant sacrifice, long hours and emotional pressure. He explained that success rarely comes instantly and that building something valuable requires patience and willingness to face failure without giving up. Many startups collapse because the desire for quick results overrides perseverance. His advice encourages young builders to stay committed to their vision, work consistently and remain grounded when setbacks appear. Hard work, combined with purpose, becomes the fuel for meaningful growth. Entrepreneurs who endure difficult phases often become the ones who eventually change industries and create progress.Entrepreneurs inspired by Musk’s message can start by observing real issues around them. Identifying everyday challenges within families, workplaces, or communities offers the strongest foundation for innovation. Instead of beginning with fundraising or branding, entrepreneurs can work on developing small prototypes and testing them directly with users. Listening to feedback, improving continuously, and prioritising quality over speed can lead to stable growth. Additionally, choosing long-term thinking helps build businesses that contribute genuine value rather than temporary excitement. Musk’s approach suggests that profits will follow naturally when a solution solves a real problem.The reason Musk’s message is spreading quickly across India is simple. It replaces pressure with purpose. It reminds young founders that meaningful contribution matters more than chasing financial success alone. In a country that is witnessing an explosion of startups and innovation, his advice encourages a mindset shift towards usefulness, resilience and long-term thinking. By focusing on building valuable products and services that help people, entrepreneurs can create lasting change and shape industries for generations. For those dreaming of success, the message is powerful: build something useful, contribute positively, and the results will follow in time.
Article Summary: In a recent episode of the popular podcast People by WTF, Elon Musk shared advice that has quickly gone viral across India. His message, directed towards young Indian entrepreneurs, emphasised the importance of focusing on building useful products and services rather than chasing wealth directly. Musk expressed admiration for creators who genuinely want to contribute something meaningful to society.

Article Title: Ford CEO says: We are in deep trouble when you compare us to China, because …
Article Text:
A national security concern



Lesson learned from COVID



A national challenge







Ford Motor company CEO Jim Farley recently shared his thoughts on America’s labour future. He revealed that the company is struggling to fill around 5,000 skilled-mechanic roles despite offering salaries around $120,000. Now once again, Farley has said that the realm crises facing America is the shortage of trade workers. In an appearance on the Office Hours: Business Edition podcast, Farley issued a warning that the US is dangerously behind countries like China when it comes with building and sustaining essential workforce. Farley didn’t mince words: “We are in deep trouble when you compare us to China,” he said, pointing to the lack of skilled labor across critical sectors. According to him, more than 1 million jobs are currently sitting empty in emergency services, trucking, plumbing, factory work, and other trades.Farley stressed that this shortage is not just about filling jobs, but it is about safeguarding the country’s ability to function in times of crises. He also argued that skilled traders are the backbone of the US economy and national resilience, but still US is failing to invest in training and education to replenish this workforce.Farley’s grandfather who worked on Ford’s assembly line, has also been vocal about the need to rebuild the pipeline for blue collar workers. “Those hardworking jobs made our country what it is,” he said. “We do not have trade schools. We are not investing in educating a next generation… of people like my grandfather who had nothing, who built a middle-class life and a future for his family.”This is the only conviction which led Ford to become the first major automaker to ratify union agreements during recent labour negotiations in both the US and Canada. “I’m so proud of us,” Farley said. “We got rid of the lower tier, paid everyone the same. Now those people have a career at Ford like my grandfather.”Farley also shared his thoughts on how the pandemic exposed the cracks present in the wage system. He said that many workers told him that they were juggling between multiple jobs in order to make the ends meet. In response to this, Ford altogether eliminated its two-tier wage structure and gave employees a clear path to financial stability, which Farley think is important for workforce rebuilding.Farley also emphasised that this not just the problem of Ford. He mentioned that the solution to this lies in public-private cooperation, education reform and cultural respect for manual work. “If we work together like we always have in America… and we get after this with the government, with education… I think we can solve this. But we have a lot of work to do.”
Article Summary: Jim Farley, CEO of Ford Motor Company, said that the US is in trouble when it comes to building and sustaining a skilled workforce. More than 1 million jobs are currently sitting empty in emergency services, trucking, plumbing, factory work, and other trades. Farley argued that skilled traders are the backbone of the US economy.

Article Title: Elon Musk tells Nikhil Kamath the name of the Indian Physicists he has named his son after
Article Text:
'US Benefited Immensely From Indians', Says Tesla CEO Elon Musk, Warns US Against Scrapping H-1B

Elon Musk’s Indian connection

Elon Musk agrees America has benefitted from talented Indians

Musk says there has been a misuse of H1-B visa





Tesla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk has now revealed that his son’s middle name Shekar is inspired by a legendary Indian-American physicist Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar, best known for his groundbreaking work on the evolution of stars. During a conversation on Nikhil Kamath’s People by WTF podcast, Musk made this revelation.Speaking at the podcast interview, Musk said, “My partner is half Indian. My son’s middle name is Sekhar, after the famous Indian physicist.” The physicist in question, Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar, won the 1983 Nobel Prize in Physics for his theoretical studies on the structure and evolution of stars, including the discovery of the Chandrasekhar limit that determines whether a star becomes a white dwarf or collapses into a black hole.The revelation made by Elon Musk underscores his personal ties to India. Elon Musk’s partner and popular musician Grimes has India heritage. Grimes once revealed that her step-father is India. Grimes once said, “My step dad’s Indian, I had a fire childhood in a half Indian household. Indian culture jives very well with western culture.”Along with this, Musk has also spoken about India’s role and importance in the global technology and energy landscape.Naming his son after Chandrasekhar reflects both a personal and symbolic connection to India’s scientific legacy.Speaking the podcast, Elon Musk also acknowledged that “America has benefitted immensely from talented Indians”, however, noted that “there has been some misuse of the H-1B Program.” Last year, Musk spoke out in defense of immigrants, specifically praising those who have significantly contributed to the US economy. He advocated for immigration of skilled workers, arguing it is essential to fill the nation’s talent gap.When asked “why has that narrative changed of late?” Musk said that “there's different schools of thought.”“And it actually also had like somewhat of a negative selection effect. So, if there's a massive financial incentive to come to the US illegally and get all these government benefits, then you're gonna necessarily create a diffusion gradient for people to come to the US. It's an incentive structure. And so, I think, that obviously made no sense.Musk also highlighted the misuse of the H1-B programme, saying that amid the need for skilled workers, there has been a misuse of the visa system.“My direct observation is that there's always a scarcity of talented people. So, from my standpoint, I'm like, ‘We have a lot of difficulty finding enough talented people to get these difficult tasks done. And so more talented people would be good’,” he said.“But I guess, some companies out there, it's sort of, they're making it more of a cost thing, where it's like, okay, if they can employ someone for a fraction of the cost of an American citizen, then, I guess, these other companies would hire people just to save costs,” Musk added.According to Musk, his companies focus on “trying to get the most talented people in the world. And we pay way above average.”
Article Summary: Tesla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk has revealed that his son’s middle name is inspired by a legendary Indian-American physicist. The physicist in question, Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar, won the 1983 Nobel Prize in Physics for his theoretical studies on the structure and evolution of stars. The revelation made by Musk underscores his personal ties to India.

Article Title: Anthropic AI cites Grokipedia instead of Wikipedia, Elon Musk responds saying: We never …
Article Text:
Elon Musk’s response: Grokipedia is an open source

'US Benefited Immensely From Indians', Says Tesla CEO Elon Musk, Warns US Against Scrapping H-1B

Grokipedia vs Wikipedia

Grokipedia’s content is largely generated or curated by the AI model Grok, whereas Wikipedia is edited and maintained by volunteer humans.

Wikipedia offers open editing, transparent revision history and community governance; Grokipedia currently limits user edits and lacks full transparency on who changed what.

Wikipedia content is freely licensed (“Creative Commons/Free) and uncoupled from commercial interests; Grokipedia is associated with a for-profit venture and uses AI systems that may embed bias.

Wikipedia hosts millions of articles across many languages and thousands of edits daily, whereas Grokipedia launched with under a million entries and is still at v0.1.

Grokipedia’s rocky start









Recently, it was observed that Anthropic’s AI tool was citing Grokipedia which is an AI-powered encyclopaedia launched by Elon Musk inplace of the widely used Wikipedia . This development prompted a question about whether there as a deeper collaboration between Anthropic and Elon Musk’s xAI, leading Musk himself to weigh in on the matter. An Australian data scientist and co-founder of fast.ai Jeremy Howard recently noticed this change while she was using Anthropic’s search API.Howard shared his observation on X, noting: “Is there some agreement between @AnthropicAI and @grok on search now? The Anthropic API today for me started citing Grokipedia sources when using its search tool, even although Wikipedia results are higher in search engines for these queries.” His post quickly drew attention, with many speculating about the reasons behind Anthropic’s apparent preference for Grokipedia over Wikipedia.Elon Musk also reposed to Howard’s post and clarified that Grokipedia is an open source and is also free to use. “ Grokipedia.com is open source and free to be used by anyone with no royalty or even acknowledgement required. We just ask that any mistakes be corrected, so that it becomes more objectively accurate over time,” wrote Musk.Musk also emphasised that the platform urges the users to correct the errors and help in improving accuracy over time, positioning Grokipedia as a collaborative and evolving knowledge base.Key differences between Grokipedia and Wikipedia are:Despite Musk’s claim that Grokipedia will be a “massive improvement” over Wikipedia, early users have flagged factual errors and ideological slants. One entry falsely claimed that former presidential candidate Vivek Ramaswamy took on a major role in DOGE after Musk’s departure, despite Ramaswamy having left months earlier.Grok, the AI chatbot behind Grokipedia, has also faced controversy. In July, it shared antisemitic content, including posts praising Adolf Hitler. xAI later apologized, attributing the incident to a flawed code update.

This development prompted a question about whether there as a deeper collaboration between Anthropic and Elon Musk's xAI.

Article Title: Zerodha CEO Nikhil Kamath asks Elon Musk ‘What did DOGE teach you’, Here’s what Tesla CEO replied
Article Text:
'US Benefited Immensely From Indians', Says Tesla CEO Elon Musk, Warns US Against Scrapping H-1B

Musk says DOGE fought against fraud









Zerodha co-founder Nikhil Kamath, in his recent podcast interview, posed multiple questions to Tesla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk . One of the queries was regarding the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), which was set up for cost-cutting measures in the government and led by Musk in the first few months of President Donald Trump's second term. Kamath asked, “What did DOGE teach you if you learned one thing?”Musk described his experience with government operations as an “interesting side quest,” detailing how people there were payment inefficiencies. He also highlighted one change that he believes could save the US government hundreds of billions of dollars annually: requiring a national payment code and a comment field with substantive information for every federal payment.“There were massive numbers of payments that were going out with no Congressional payment code, and with nothing in the comment field, which makes auditing the payments impossible,” Musk stated, adding this “trivial seeming change” could save $100 billion, or even $200 billion a year.Musk said that when efforts are made to stop fraudulent and wasteful payments, the entities responsible do not concede. Instead, they leverage sympathetic arguments to defend their funding.Musk recounted instances where he encountered claims that specific funding was essential for “needy people” or “children in Africa.” However, when pressed for verification, the claims fell apart.“We're not going to send the money unless we can talk to the recipients and confirm they will actually get it,” he emphasised.Musk also gave an example of how people used sympathy to take money from the government.“Fraudsters necessarily will come up with a very sympathetic argument. They're not going to say, 'Give us the money for fraud’. It's going to be like the 'Save the Baby Pandas' NGO, which is like, who doesn't want to save the baby pandas? They're adorable,” Musk said, followed by laughter.“But then it turns out no pandas are being saved in this thing. It's just corruption, essentially. And you're like, 'Well, can you send us a picture of the panda?' They're like, 'No.' 'Okay. Well, how do we know it's going to the pandas then?'" he added.
Article Summary: Zerodha co-founder Nikhil Kamath posed multiple questions to Tesla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk. One of the queries was regarding the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), set up for cost-cutting measures in the government. Musk described his experience with government operations as an “interesting side quest,” detailing how people there were payment inefficiencies.

Article Title: Government to Apple, Samsung, Xiaomi, Vivo, Oppo, OnePlus and other smartphone companies: Make sure all phones launched have this app pre-installed
Article Text:
What is Sanchar Saathi app





The government of India is reportedly mandating smartphone companies to ensure that all their smartphones come with the official cyber security app. According to a report in Reuters, telecom ministry has privately asked smartphone makers to preload all new devices with a state-owned cyber security app that cannot be deleted. The report claims to quote a government order that Reuters says it has seen. The government cyber security app that Apple, Samsung, Xiaomi, Vivo, Oppo, OnePlus and other smartphone companies have been told to pre-install is: Sanchar Saathi app.The government order, dated November 28, gives major smartphone companies 90 days to ensure that the government's Sanchar Saathi app is pre-installed on new mobile phones, with a provision that users cannot disable it. For devices already in the supply chain, manufacturers should push the app to phones via software updates, the telecom ministry reportedly said in its order. The report says that has not been made public as yet and was sent privately to select companies. The government says that the app helps prevent cyber threats and assists tracking and blocking of lost or stolen phones, helping police to trace devices, while keeping counterfeits out of the black market.The Department of Telecommunications (DoT) introduced the Sanchar Saathi mobile app in January 2025. According to telecom department, the citizen-centric tool brings robust security features and fraud-reporting capabilities directly to users’ smartphones. The app complements the existing Sanchar Saathi portal by providing convenient, on-the-go protection against identity theft, forged KYC, device theft, banking fraud, and other cyber risks. Sanchar Saathi app is mainly designed to help users block and track lost or stolen smartphones across all telecom networks, using a central registry. It also lets them identify, and disconnect, fraudulent mobile connections.As per government data, since its launch on January 17, 2025, the Sanchar Saathi mobile app has crossed 50 lakh downloads as on August 2025. Over 37.28 lakh stolen/lost mobile devices have been successfully blocked and more than 22.76 lakh devices have been traced from the Sanchar Saathi LIVE dashboard.One of the world's largest telephone markets, India has more than 1.2 billion subscribers. As per government figures, the app has helped recover more than 700,000 lost phones, including 50,000 in October alone. With more than 5 million downloads since its launch, the app has helped block more than 3.7 million stolen or lost mobile phones, while more than 30 million fraudulent connections have also been terminated.The app is available in Hindi and 21 other regional languages, making it inclusive and accessible across the country.
Article Summary: The government is reportedly mandating smartphone companies to pre-install the Sanchar Saathi app. The app is a state-owned cyber security app that cannot be deleted. The government says that the app helps prevent cyber threats and assists tracking and blocking of lost or stolen phones, helping police to trace devices, while keeping counterfeits out of the black market.
